case_name: Instalment Supply P Ltd. v. Gujarat State

facts.text: Writ petition Nos. 129, 131 of 1969 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution of India

anchor.surface_text: Writ petition Nos. 129, 131 of 1969.  Petition Under Article 32 of the Constitution of India . Ved Vyas, Bishamber Lal, H. K. Puri, P. V. Kapur and S. C. Patel, for the petitioner.

facts.text: Judgment delivered by ALAGIRISWAMI, J.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by- ALAGIRISWAMI, J. The very same question that arises in these three petitions,

facts.text: Petitioner is a limited company with registered office in New Delhi

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner is a limited companypany with its registered office in New Delhi. It carries on the business of financing the purchase of motor vehicles.

facts.text: Petitioner carries on business of financing the purchase of motor vehicles

anchor.surface_text: It carries on the business of financing the purchase of motor vehicles. The person desiring to purchase a motor vehicle enters into a hire- purchase agreement with the petitioner companypany.

facts.text: Person desiring to purchase motor vehicle enters into hire-purchase agreement with petitioner company

anchor.surface_text: The person desiring to purchase a motor vehicle enters into a hire- purchase agreement with the petitioner companypany. It may be useful to give within a short companypass the terms of the agreement The companypany

facts.text: Company charges hirer initial deposit by way of premium, usually 25% of price for new vehicles, becomes absolute property of company

anchor.surface_text: The companypany charges the hirer an initial deposit by way of premium as a companysideration for granting the lease of the vehicle, which deposit becomes the absolute property of the companypany, the premium charged as aforesaid is a substantial amount, being usually 25 of the prices in respect of new vehicles.

facts.text: Hirer undertakes to pay instalments and when all paid, vehicle becomes property of hirer at option on payment of rupee one

anchor.surface_text: The hirer undertakes to pay instalments and when all the instalments are paid, the vehicle becomes the property of the hirer at his option, on payment of rupee one to the companypany, as a companysideration for the option

facts.text: Until all instalments paid and option exercised, vehicle remains property of company

anchor.surface_text: until all the stipulated instalments have been paid and the option exercised as aforesaid, the vehicle remains the property of the companypany as owners. The hirer is delivered possession of the vehicle

facts.text: Hirer delivered possession of vehicle and responsible for damage, destruction or loss

anchor.surface_text: The hirer is delivered possession of the vehicle and he remains responsible to the companypany for damage or destruction or loss. The hirer has to pay interest at the rate of one per cent per mensem

facts.text: Hirer pays interest at one per cent per mensem on overdue sums

anchor.surface_text: The hirer has to pay interest at the rate of one per cent per mensem on all sums overdue. Until the option of purchase is exercised by the hirer he is at liberty to return the vehicle

facts.text: Until option exercised, hirer at liberty to return vehicle and end hiring agreement on certain terms

anchor.surface_text: Until the option of purchase is exercised by the hirer he is at liberty to return the vehicle and to put an end to the hiring agreement, on certain terms. Thus, under the agreement the hirer has the use of the vehicle

facts.text: Petitioner was party to earlier litigation Instalment Supply P Ltd. v. Union of India, 1962 2 SCR 644

anchor.surface_text: The very same question that arises in these three petitions, though from a different angle, was companysidered by this Court in an earlier litigation to which the Petitioner was a party  Instalment Supply  P  Ltd. v. Union of India, 1962 2 SCR 644.

facts.text: In earlier case, Delhi State sought to tax transactions under hire-purchase agreements

anchor.surface_text: The question is when does sale liable to sales tax take place under a hire purchase agreement. On the earlier occasion it was the Delhi State that sought to tax certain transactions under hire-purchase agreements

facts.text: In present case, Gujarat State sought to tax certain transactions under hire-purchase agreements

anchor.surface_text: In the present case it is the Gujarat State that has sought to tax certain transactions under certain hire- purchase agreements. The, petitioner is a limited companypany with its registered office

facts.text: Contract of hire purchase entered into in Delhi, instalments paid in Delhi, option exercised in Delhi

anchor.surface_text: The fact that in this case the companytract of hire purchase was entered into in Delhi,that the instalments were paid in Delhi and the option itself was exercised in Delhi does number make any difference to this result.

facts.text: Actual sale fructified when hirer exercised option to purchase and at that time goods were inside State of Gujarat

anchor.surface_text: The actual sale in this case fructified only when the hirer exercised his option to purchase under the hire purchase agreement and at that time goods were inside the State of Gujarat.

facts.text: Petitions dismissed

anchor.surface_text: The petitions are dismissed. There will, however, be numberorder as to companyts.

facts.text: Bengal Finance Sales Tax Act 1941 extended to State of Delhi

anchor.surface_text: The liability to sales tax on the earlier occasion arose under the Bengal Finance  Sales Tax  Act, 1941, which was extended to the State of Delhi.

facts.text: Definition of sale in Delhi Act amended in 1959 by Act 20 of 1959

anchor.surface_text: We may however point out that the definition of sale in the Bengal Finance  Sales Tax  Act applicable to the State of Delhi has been amended in 1959 by Act 20 of 1959

facts.text: Petition under Art 32 maintainable as constitutionality of s.2(28) of Gujarat Act questioned

anchor.surface_text: The companystitutionality of s.2 28  of the Gujarat Act has been questioned, and therefore the petition is maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: The question is when does sale liable to sales tax take place under a hire purchase agreement. On the earlier occasion it was the Delhi State that sought to tax certain transactions under hire-purchase agreements

anchor.surface_text: The constitutionality of s.2(28) of the Gujarat Act has been questioned, and therefore the petition is maintainable.

arguments.claim: No State legislature is competent to enact legislation making hire-purchase agreement a deemed sale

anchor.surface_text: But no State legislature is competent to enact a legislation which would make a hire- purchase agreement a deemed sale. It was so held in Johars case by this Court.

arguments.claim: Hire-purchase agreement ripens into a sale when option to purchase is exercised after fulfilling terms

anchor.surface_text: The next question that arises is whether a hire purchase agreement ever ripens into a sale and if so when. We have already pointed out that a hire purchase agreement has two elements i element of bailment, and ii element of sale

anchor.surface_text: The actual sale in this case fructified only when the hirer exercised his option to purchase under the hire purchase agreement and at that time goods were inside the State of Gujarat.

arguments.court_reasoning: Sale completed by property passing in Gujarat where goods situated

arguments.claim: No objection to incorporation in Gujarat Act s.2(28) of definition from Central Sales Tax Act s.4(2)

anchor.surface_text: We see no objection to the incorporation in section 2(28) of the Gujarat Act of the-definition of a sale inside a State contained in s.4(2) of the Central Sales Tax Act.

arguments.claim: Gujarat State can tax sale inside the State even if goods previously taxed by Delhi State

anchor.surface_text: Nor do we see any objection, to Gujarat levying a tax in respect of same goods even though those, goods may have been subjected, to tax earlier by the Delhi State. There is no rule that any goods can be subjected to tax, only once

arguments.claim: Parliament competent to deem hire-purchase as sale for tax due to plenary power under Entry 97 List I

anchor.surface_text: This was on the basis that the power of Parliament to legislate in respect of Part C States is untrammelled by the limitation prescribed by Art. 246, Cls. 2 and 3 , and Entry 54 of List II, and is plenary and absolute

arguments.claim: Sale of goods liable to sales tax takes place under hire-purchase when option exercised

anchor.surface_text: The question is when does sale liable to sales tax take place under a hire purchase agreement. On the earlier occasion it was the Delhi State that sought to tax certain transactions under hire-purchase agreements

arguments.claim: Gujarat Act s.2(28) definition of sale applies to actual sale in hire-purchase, not deeming the agreement

anchor.surface_text: In the present case section 2(28) of the Gujarat Act defines sale as follows Sale means a sale of goods made within the State for cash or deferred payment or other valuable consideration

holdings.text: A hire-purchase agreement ripens into a sale when the hirer exercises the option to purchase after fulfilling all terms of the agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The next question that arises is whether a hire purchase agreement ever ripens into a sale and if so when. We have already pointed out that a hire purchase agreement has two elements  i  element of bailment, and

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies definition from Sale of Goods Act s.4 distinguishing agreement to sell from sale; element of sale fructifies on exercise of option after terms satisfied; follows precedents in Instalment Supply and Johar cases.

holdings.text: The sale liable to sales tax under hire-purchase agreement takes place when the option to purchase is exercised by the hirer after payment of all instalments.

anchor.surface_text: The element of sale fructifies when the option is exercised by the intending purchaser after fulfilling the terms of the agreement. When all the terms of the agreement are satisfied and the option is exercised a sale takes place

holdings.reasoning_summary: Taxable event is the sale; follows Johar case holding tax levy only when option exercised; distinguishes from earlier Instalment Supply where Parliament deemed agreement taxable.

holdings.text: No State legislature is competent to enact legislation deeming a hire-purchase agreement a sale.

anchor.surface_text: But no State legislature is competent to enact a legislation which would make a hire- purchase agreement a deemed sale. It was so held in Johars case by this Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Johar case; contrasts with Parliament's plenary power under Entry 97 List I for Part C States; State limited by Entry 54 List II.

holdings.text: The Gujarat Sales Tax Act s.2(28) is constitutional as it defines and taxes an actual sale within the State, not deeming the hire-purchase agreement itself a sale.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case section 2(28) of the Gujarat Act defines sale as follows Sale means a sale of goods made within the State for cash or deferred payment or other valuable consideration

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definition mirrors ordinary sale; applies to moment option exercised; no legal fiction expanding sale concept beyond legislative competence.

holdings.text: The sale under the hire-purchase agreement took place inside the State of Gujarat because the goods were within Gujarat when the hirer exercised the option to purchase.

anchor.surface_text: The actual sale in this case fructified only when the hirer exercised his option to purchase under the hire purchase agreement and at that time goods were inside the State of Gujarat.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies s.4(2) Central Sales Tax Act via incorporation in Gujarat Act s.2(28) Explanation; property passes where goods situated at time of sale completion.

holdings.text: Facts that hire-purchase contract entered, instalments paid, and option exercised in Delhi do not alter that the sale took place in Gujarat.

anchor.surface_text: The fact that in this case the contract of hire purchase was entered into in Delhi,that the instalments were paid in Delhi and the option itself was exercised in Delhi does not make any difference to this result.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sale completed by passing of property in goods situated in Gujarat; agreement concluded in Delhi but sale in Gujarat.

holdings.text: No objection to Gujarat Act s.2(28) incorporating principles of Central Sales Tax Act s.4(2) for determining sale inside the State.

anchor.surface_text: We see no objection to the incorporation in section 2(28) of the Gujarat Act of the-definition of a sale inside a State contained in s.4(2) of the Central Sales Tax Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction; equivalent to direct incorporation; competent for State to adopt for intra-state sales.

holdings.text: Gujarat entitled to tax sale even if goods previously taxed by Delhi; no rule against multiple sales tax on same goods.

anchor.surface_text: Nor do we see any objection, to Gujarat levying a tax in respect of same goods even though those, goods may have been subjected, to tax earlier by the Delhi State. There is no rule that any goods can be subjected to tax, only once

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sales tax multi-point; distinct sales (agreement vs actual sale); Parliament's fiction taxed agreement, State taxes sale.

holdings.text: Petition under Article 32 maintainable as constitutionality of Gujarat Act s.2(28) questioned.

anchor.surface_text: The constitutionality of s.2(28) of the Gujarat Act has been questioned, and therefore the petition is maintainable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Ujjam Bai case: Art 32 lies where statute ultra vires.
